awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:   Genetic analysis of elk scat for diversity and diet
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology.  The fellow, a Yurok tribal member, will expand ongoing research in the integration of Indigenous and Western science approaches to wildlife conservation.  Strong collaborations between the fellow, Humboldt State University, the Yurok Tribe of California, the Spokane Tribe of Washington, and Redwood National Park will serve as a model for facilitating research under various management types.  The fellow will focus on Traditional Ecological Knowledge and a genetic analysis of elk fecal samples from Yurok ancestral lands and the Spokane reservation to identify individuals and diet.  The fellow will also conduct outreach activities in both tribal communities, as well as, at national conferences and Humboldt State University.  The project and outreach activities will serve tribal communities by highlighting Indigenous science and providing opportunities to inspire and engage people of all ages in science.  The research will serve the broader society by providing an example of an integrated scientific approach, as well as contributing to the scientific literature on genetic diversity and diet of these elk populations.

Yurok Traditional Ecological Knowledge as related to elk will be integrated with the Yurok portion of this study through the analysis of interviews with Yurok-affiliated community members.  The successful Spokane elk management program will inform potential management strategies for Yurok, where the elk population is limited as compared to surrounding lands.  Genotyping of individuals will be conducted through the amplification of 11 polymorphic microsatellite markers specifically designed for elk and the calculation of Probability of Identity.  Plant samples will be collected and analyzed to create a reference library of DNA sequences with which to compare diet items from the fecal samples.  Diet will be determined via metabarcoding and shotgun sequencing analyses, with subsequent sequence matching in the Basic Local Alignment Search Tool available through the National Center for Biotechnology Information.  Training activities will include wet lab techniques for elk individual identification and diet, as well as attendance at bioinformatics workshops.  Broadening participation activities will include outreach to tribal peoples, from youth to college level, and engagement with students from various backgrounds at Humboldt State University.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Wildlife conservation is of high priority for wildlife ecologists and many Indigenous communities. However, Indigenous histories, present-day narratives and Indigenous peoples have been marginalized in Western academic institutions and scientific disciplines. Indigenous scholars have advocated that research conducted with Indigenous communities should respect their worldviews, forms of government, communities, and culture. My overarching goal as an Indigenous/Chicana woman in STEM and NSF postdoctoral research fellow in the broadening participation emphasis was to refine my framework in wildlife research with Indigenous communities that is both ecologically meaningful and culturally sensitive. My proposed research focused on the application of fecal genetics methods to investigate elk diet and genetic diversity in Yurok ancestral lands. However, given the systemic barriers to minorities in STEM, I prioritized publication of manuscripts remaining from my dissertation to strengthen my candidacy for a permanent position in science. I have integrated Indigenous Research Methodologies (IRM), Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK), and conventional wildlife research, thus creating a new trajectory in the wildlife field that expands the inclusive space of Indigenous peoples and Indigeneity while producing research that meets [Western] scientific standards. 

In my doctoral program, I conducted interdisciplinary research with the Yurok Tribe of northwestern California to understand TEK through the Yurok cultural lens. I also conducted a wildlife scat genetics study on Yurok ancestral lands. With the support of the NSF postdoc, I published the Yurok TEK research in the top journal of my professional society, the Journal of Wildlife Management. I later learned that only three TEK papers have been published in the society's journals in the past decade, and that two of them are authored by me. This achievement is a direct result of the postdoc.

One of the aims of my research is to apply IRM and TEK to facilitate a culturally sensitive approach. As language is a component of TEK, I decided during my postdoc to include a story in the Yurok language as a companion piece to the scat genetics manuscript. I partnered with colleagues to propose and serve as associate editors for a special issue, Indigenous Contributions to Molecular Ecology, in the journal Molecular Ecology Resources, as a potential outlet for this research. The special issue was approved and is in progress.

The training and independence afforded by this fellowship allowed me to showcase my framework in tenure-track faculty interviews. One of the crowning achievements of my postdoc was to accept an offer for Assistant Professor of Indigenous Forestry in the School of Forestry at Northern Arizona University (NAU), where I will pursue research and educate future generations of scientists for decades to come. To the department's knowledge, this position is the only one of its kind in the world. The significance of this position led to my participation in an invited televised interview on Indian Country Today.

During my postdoc, I have worked on additional manuscripts and have moved the proposed elk fecal genetics project forward by collaborating with Redwood National Park, the Yurok Tribe, and the Culver Conservation Genetics Laboratory at The University of Arizona. Through professional relationships developed during the fellowship, I will continue this project with the Mammalian Ecology Conservation Unit, UC Davis. 

Under my fellowship, I have worked to broaden participation of groups underrepresented in STEM. During the COVID-19 shutdown, I collaborated virtually with partners, such as a non-profit, Science Delivered, to co-develop a set of elementary level TEK and wildlife lessons that are available online for free. The lessons have been used by instructors across the United States, reaching hundreds of students from kindergarten to college level. I developed and delivered a workshop for Indigenous college students in natural resources. I have presented to students from elementary to college, as well as Indigenous communities, and have shared my research with the broader scientific community at seminars and conferences. I have mentored over 15 students from various backgrounds. One student mentee and I have a co-authored manuscript in production stage for a first-of-its-kind volume on Tribal Wildlife Management. Additionally, I have served three years as a committee member of the Native Student Professional Development Program, under the Native Peoples Wildlife Management Working Group of The Wildlife Society. 

I have advocated for the inclusion of Indigenous languages as TEK and Indigenous science in STEM and participated in a Yurok language teacher candidate program, where I earned my teaching credential for Yurok levels I and II. Last and certainly not least, I have maintained commitments with my Indigenous communities as a TEK practitioner. While research and output are important in STEM academia, more inclusivity of Indigenous peoples will likely require new models. While under my fellowship, and with support from NAU, I was able to forge such a model in my faculty position, starting by working remotely and including a service component of Indigenous community engagement.
